newsitem.title: GABON: Zaire's Mobutu arrives in Gabon for summit.
newsitem.headline: Zaire's Mobutu arrives in Gabon for summit.

text.p: Zaire's President Mobutu Sese Seko, battling cancer and rebel advances, arrived in Gabon's capital Libreville on Wednesday on a visit that raised speculation at home that he had left for good.
Witnesses said that Mobutu, who was with his wife Bobi Ladawa, looked tired and went straight to a waiting vehicle.
Mobutu aides in Kinshasa, which rebels say they are poised to capture, said he would attend a regional mini-summit in Libreville on efforts to broker peace in his troubled country.
"The president will go to Libreville on Wednesday and will return on Friday," spokesman Kabuya Lumuna said on Tuesday.
Gabon's president, Omar Bongo, host of the latest Zaire summit, welcomed the man who has dominated Africa's third largest country for over three decades.

Gabon's government newspaper, L'Union, reported that the summit would take place on Thursday and would bring together Mobutu, Bongo and the presidents of Congo, Central African Republic and Equatorial Guinea.
A Zairean government statement on Tuesday said the presidents of Cameroon and Chad would attend.

The talks were a follow-up to a weekend peace summit between Mobutu, rebel leader Laurent Kabila and South Africa's Nelson Mandela on a South African ship in the Congolese port of Pointe Noire, it added. That meeting proved inconclusive.
Mandela said he would convene fresh talks within 10 days.
Mobutu, 66, has seen his hold over Zaire, broken by a whirlwind rebel offensive. Kabila and his commanders, who took up arms in October, say they are building up for a final push against the capital.
